page.title: 01Surrounding St Ewe,Cornwall
page.content: Wholly agricultural area, landcover principally grassland.Intensive on flatter areas, semi intensive on hilly areas, some barley, wheat and potatoes grown. Only two sizeable woodland areas still in existence, i.e. Trelean plantation and heligan estate. Heligan house is the property of the Tremaynes, and dates from 1604 renovated 1810. Trevithick is a tudor farmhouse, and Trelewack is on a site mentioned in Domesday book. Most farmhoues are built of stone, and many cottages are cob built, often faced with stone. Nunnery Hill is wooded site of Nunnery was N E of this point. River Luney flows n/s from Luney barton to Porthluney (Caerhays) reputedly it was navigable to bridge at Polmassick, a small vineyard exists there today. Kestle is hamlet on edge of the Heligan Estate.
